  </td>

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;"><a href="#Item10_DirectorsAndExecutiveOfficer" title="Click to goto ITEM 10.   AND EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANT</a></font></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="center" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><a name="PartI"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">PART I</font></font></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="Item1_Business"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">ITEM 1.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; BUSINESS</font></font></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="Overview"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Overview</font></font></u></b></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Schnitzer Steel

Industries, Inc. (the Company) and its joint venture businesses collect,

process and recycle metals by operating one of the largest metals recycling

businesses in the United States.&#160; The

Company also manufactures finished steel products at its technologically

advanced steel mini-mill (the Steel Manufacturing Business).&#160; As a result of its vertically integrated

business, the Company is able to transform auto bodies and other unprocessed

metals into finished steel products.&#160;

The Company believes that its Metals Recycling and Steel Manufacturing

Businesses are cost competitive in their markets.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company's wholly

owned recycling business (the Metals Recycling Business) and its joint ventures

have major collection and processing facilities in the following locations:</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="80%" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:1.0in;width:80.0%;">

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <h6 style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-decoration:underline;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Metals

  Recycling Business</font></font></u></h6>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="56%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:56.74%;">

  <h6 style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-decoration:underline;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Joint

  Venture Operations</font></font></u></h6>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="56%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:56.74%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Portland, OR</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="56%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:56.74%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Jersey City, NJ</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Oakland, CA</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="56%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:56.74%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Long Island, NY</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Tacoma, WA</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Los Angeles, CA</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Sacramento, CA</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="56%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:56.74%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Everett, MA</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Eugene OR</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="56%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:56.74%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Providence, RI</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="38%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:38.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Fresno, CA</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:4.88%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="56%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:56.74%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

 </tr>

</table>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The Metals Recycling Business&#146; twelve

yards sold 1.5 million ferrous tons in fiscal 2001&#160; Additionally, through joint ventures, the Company participates in

the management of an additional 28 metals recycling collection and processing

facilities<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">.&#160;

These joint ventures sold 3.1 million ferrous tons in fiscal 2001.&#160; Additionally, these joint ventures provide

international and domestic services which broker approximately 1.3 million tons

per year.</font></font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">As the steel industry in

the United States consolidates, the Company believes it is well positioned to

remain a leader in the metals recycling and steel-making industries.&#160; In addition, it is anticipated that the

demand for recycled ferrous metals will increase due to the continued

transformation of the world&#146;s steel producers from virgin iron ore based blast

furnaces to newer, technologically advanced electric arc furnace (EAF)

mini-mills. In the last 25 years, steel production using recycled metals and

the EAF process has grown dramatically. The EAF process, which uses 85-95%

recycled metal compared with the traditional steel-making process that uses

less than 35% recycled metal, is more environmentally sound and energy

efficient.&#160; By recycling steel, limited

natural resources are preserved and the need to disrupt the environment with

the mining of virgin iron ore is greatly reduced.&#160; Further, when recycled metal, instead of iron ore is used for new

steel production, air and water pollution generated by the production process

decreases.&#160; Currently, almost half of

U.S. steel and much of foreign-based steel is produced using the EAF process.&#160; China, the world&#146;s largest steel producing

country, uses the EAF technology to produce only 18% of its steel.&#160; Industry analysts have projected China&#146;s EAF

based production to increase to approximately 35% by the year 2005. Today,

China is the Company&#146;s, and many of its joint ventures&#146;, largest destination

for its recycled metal products.&#160; Using

the EAF process to produce new steel makes the recycled ferrous metal commodity

a strategic raw material for both domestic and foreign markets.&#160; This benefits the Company and its joint

ventures in the metals recycling business due to their strategic geographic

locations at many of the major deep-sea ports in the United States.&#160; This allows the Company and its joint

ventures the option of supplying the domestic steel mills as well as foreign

steel producers.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company's Steel Manufacturing Business is conducted

by its wholly owned subsidiary, Cascade Steel Rolling Mills, Inc.&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business produces

steel reinforcing bar (rebar), wire rod, merchant bar, coiled rebar, fence

posts, specialty sections and grape stakes.&#160;

The Company believes that the Steel Manufacturing Business has a strong

competitive position in its market due to its readily available source of

recycled metals, efficient production processes, state-of-the-art technology,

well-located shipping and transportation facilities, access to competitively

priced hydroelectric power, and proximity to California and other major western

markets.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="BusinessStrategy"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Business

Strategy</font></font></u></b></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s business

strategy emphasizes continued growth of the ferrous recycled metals business

through additive acquisitions and joint ventures, and maintaining its status as

a low-cost producer of both recycled metal and finished steel products through

investments in state-of-the-art manufacturing equipment and increased

production efficiencies.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company considers

itself, first and foremost, a ferrous metals recycling company, with

historically over 60% of its operating income, before corporate expenses and

eliminations, derived from the Metals Recycling Business and its Joint Ventures

in the Metals Recycling Business.&#160; The

Metals Recycling Business is one of the leading processors in each of the

markets in which it operates.&#160; Future

capital expenditures will focus largely on increasing the Company&#146;s position as

one of the premier recycled metals processors in the country.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company&#146;s Metals Recycling Business enters into sales

contracts by selling forward 45 to 90 days and purchases unprocessed metals on

a daily basis. The typical supplier is a relatively small, local business or

manufacturer who sells unprocessed metals in limited quantities.&#160; The typical supplier generally does not have

the ability to inventory material in significant quantities, and therefore

lacks the market leverage to influence prices.&#160;

By knowing the price for which the processed material will be sold and

the costs involved in processing the metals, the Company is generally able to

take advantage of this differential in timing between purchases and sales and

negotiate prices with suppliers that secure profitable transactions.&#160; However, the Asian financial crisis that

occurred during fiscal 1998 and 1999 caused recycled metals selling prices to

drop faster than the Company was able to decrease purchase prices for

unprocessed metals.&#160; Also, in order to

ensure an adequate inflow of unprocessed metals, the Company had to maintain

certain minimum purchase price levels.&#160;

As the recycled metals markets stabilized, the Company was able to

regain a portion of the margins and virtually all of the volume it had lost as

a result of the Asian financial crisis.&#160;

Although the Asian economies have generally improved from the crisis

levels, the Company continues to operate in a very competitive market.&#160; During the last two years, the Company has

seen unusually large volumes of good quality ferrous recycled metals come from

the former Soviet Union, primarily from the Ukraine and other Black Sea

countries.&#160; These countries have exported

their products to many of the Company&#146;s traditional markets (e.g., South Korea,

Japan and Turkey).</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company has developed a multi-part growth strategy,

which includes the following elements:</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Expand Metals Recycling Operations.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160; The Company will continue to seek expansion

opportunities for its Metals Recycling Business within both its existing

markets and elsewhere in North America.&#160;

The Company has focused on and will continue to emphasize increasing its

sources of <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">unprocessed </font>ferrous<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;"> metals </font>through its existing network and

through selective acquisitions or through joint ventures with <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals </font>processors and suppliers.&#160; Examples include:</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; During fiscal 1998, the Company and one of

its joint venture partners increased their East Coast market position through

the buyout of a third joint venture partner and the completion of two other

strategic joint venture acquisitions;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In November 1996, the Company acquired

Proler International Corp. (Proler).&#160;

Proler&#146;s joint ventures process approximately 3 million long tons of

ferrous <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals </font>per year;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In March 1995, the Company purchased

Manufacturing Management, Inc. (MMI), another <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals

</font>processor which added approximately 500,000 long tons per year to the

Company&#146;s ferrous <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">recycled metals </font>volume;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In December 1993, the Company acquired

four <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals </font>collection and processing

facilities in central and southern Oregon.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has also made a series of

investments in other joint ventures, which increase the Company&#146;s sources of <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">unprocessed metals </font>supply.&#160; The Company&#146;s most significant joint venture,

in this regard, operates self-service used auto parts yards, primarily in

California.&#160; This joint venture operates

under the name of Pick-N-Pull Auto Dismantlers (Pick-N-Pull).&#160; The Company&#146;s Oakland facility receives car

bodies from Pick-N-Pull for processing and sale as shredded <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">recycled metal</font>.</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Complete Additive Acquisitions.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; </font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company intends to complete acquisitions it believes will earn

income, after tax, in excess of its cost of capital.&#160; Over the past several years, particularly before the Asian

financial crisis created uncertainty in the recycled metals industry, several

companies in the metals recycling business acquired other recycled metals

companies at prices which the Company believes were unjustifiably high.&#160; The Asian financial crisis coupled with the

current world-wide economic slowdown has since caused significant dislocations

in the recycled metals industry.&#160; It is

the Company&#146;s belief that, as a result of these dislocations, some of these acquired

companies may again become available at attractive prices. With a strong

balance sheet, cash flows and available borrowing capacity, the Company

believes it is in an attractive position to complete an acquisition should one

fitting the Company&#146;s long-term strategic plans become available and if a

reasonable price can be attained.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Invest in State-of-the-Art Processing and Manufacturing.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160; </font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">The

Company&#146;s objective is to be a low cost producer of both <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">recycled metals </font>and finished steel products

in order to maximize the operating margin for both operations.&#160; To meet this objective, the Company has

focused on and will continue to emphasize the efficient purchasing and

processing of <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals</font>.&#160; Additionally, the Company has made

significant investments in state-of-the art equipment to ensure that its operations

have cost effective technology to produce high quality products and to maximize

economies of scale.&#160; The Company

continues to invest in equipment to improve the efficiency and capabilities of

its businesses.&#160; During the last five

years the Company has spent $61.7 million on capital improvements.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">In fiscal 2001, the Company began installation of a

static var compensator at the Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; mini-mill which,

when completed in late 2001, will provide a more uniform power supply to the

steel making process.&#160; In addition, the

Portland, Oregon metals recycling facility is installing a dewatering process

that removes water from auto shredder residue.&#160;

This residue is then sent to landfills for disposal.&#160; By removing water from the residue, the

Company will lower the water content by approximately 40%, thereby reducing

weight and disposal costs.&#160; Also, the

same facility installed an eddy current separator, which recovers more

high-valued nonferrous metal from the auto shredding process.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">During fiscal 2000, the Company completed

the installation of a state-of-the-art automobile shredder, capable of

shredding over 2,000 tons per day, at its Tacoma facility.&#160; This shredder replaced two obsolete shredders

that on a combined basis were capable of producing only 1,000 tons per

day.&#160; The new shredder is reducing

operating costs and has improved product quality; as well, it has allowed the

Tacoma metals recycling facility to shred material that was previously sold as

lower valued materials.&#160; Additionally,

the dock and bulkhead at the Tacoma facility were rebuilt during fiscal 1999 to

more efficiently handle the increased shredder capacity, the exporting of

metals and receipt of bulk unprocessed metals from Alaska.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Economic

Value Added.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160;

In fiscal year 2001, the Company implemented an Economic Value Added

(EVA&#174;) financial measurement and compensation system.&#160; EVA measures the value of, and guides, economic decision making

based on established return on investment criteria that the Company believes

meets the expectations of the financial markets.&#160; Decisions made under EVA are designed to create long-term,

sustainable value.&#160; In addition, under

EVA decision making is decentralized and provides managers with the financial

analysis tools to make better decisions.&#160;

Managers&#146; incentive pay is directly linked to success in creating value

and is designed to motivate and reward reasonable and sensible risk

taking.&#160; EVA measures and evaluates the

performance of the Company and its employees by explicitly recognizing the cost

of equity, as well as debt, capital and quantifying the results.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Increase Finished Steel Production and

Product Flexibility.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; </font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">In February 1996, a second rolling mill

(Rolling Mill #2) was completed, increasing the <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Steel Manufacturing Business</font>&#146; production capacity.&#160; Additionally, in February 1997, the Company

completed the installation of a rod block at Rolling Mill #2.&#160; The rod block has allowed the Company to

enhance and diversify its product mix through the production of coiled rebar

and wire rod.&#160; In addition, the ability

of the new bar mill to produce existing cut-to-length rebar products permits

the Company to increase its production of higher-margin merchant bar products

at Rolling Mill #1 and also increases the Company&#146;s flexibility to adjust its

product mix among rebar, merchant bar and wire rod products to respond to

relative demand and price conditions among these products and to maximize

profits.&#160; Rolling Mill #2 expands the

Company&#146;s rolling capacity, based on anticipated product mix, to about 700,000

tons annually.&#160; The Company does not

expect to expand the <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Steel Manufacturing

Business</font> through significant capital additions in the foreseeable

future.</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Capture Benefits of Integration.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Company has historically

sought to capture the potential benefits of business integration whenever

possible.&#160; The Company believes it

enjoys a competitive advantage over non-vertically integrated mini-mill steel

producers as a result of its extensive metals recycling operation.&#160; The Metals Recycling Business ensures the

Steel Manufacturing Business will receive a predictable, high quality supply of

recycled metals in an optimal mix of grades for efficient melting.&#160; Likewise, the Steel Manufacturing Business

ensures a steady market for a portion of the Metals Recycling Business&#146;

production.&#160; In the Steel Manufacturing

Business, the Company's wire rod and bar mill has upgraded and continues to

upgrade the Company's finished steel production and product mix.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company leverages a portion of shared administrative

services with certain of its joint venture partners and related companies which

reduces the cost of these services to the Company.&#160; These relationships also provide the Company with expertise

related to real estate and ocean shipping management.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="MetalsRecyclingBusiness"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Metals

Recycling Business</font></font></u></b></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is one of the

largest metals processors in the United States, with twelve wholly owned metals

collection and processing facilities.&#160;

The Company buys, processes and sells ferrous metals to foreign and domestic

steel producers or their representatives and to the Steel Manufacturing

Business.&#160; The Metals Recycling Business

also purchases metal from other recycled metals processors for shipment

directly to the Steel Manufacturing Business without further processing by the

Metals Recycling Business.&#160; To a lesser

extent, the Company also buys, processes and sells nonferrous metals to both

the domestic and export markets.&#160; A

significant portion of the nonferrous volume comes as a by-product of the

automobile shredding process.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Due to the large capital

investment required for metals recycling equipment and the scarcity of

potential yard sites that are properly zoned and have access to waterways,

highways and railroads, the recycled metals industry is characterized by a

relatively small number of large, regionally dominant metals processors.&#160; These large processors collect raw metals

from a variety of sources, including smaller metal recyclers and dealers, and

then sort, clean and cut it into sizes and grades suitable for use by steel

manufacturers.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company's

Portland, Oakland, and Tacoma metals recycling facilities are located at deep

water terminals operated by the Company and also have rail and highway

access.&#160; The Company owns the Oakland

and Tacoma facilities and leases the Portland location from a related

party.&#160; As a result, the Company

believes it is strategically located, both for collection of unprocessed metals

from suppliers and for distribution of processed recycled metals to West Coast

and foreign steel producers.&#160;

Additionally, because the Company operates the terminal facilities, it

is not subject to berthing delays often experienced by users of unaffiliated

terminals.&#160; The Company&#146;s loading costs

are believed to be lower than they would be if the Company were to utilize

third party terminal facilities.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Customers and Marketing</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">.&#160; The following table sets forth

information about the amount of ferrous recycled metals sold by the Company's

Metals Recycling Business to certain groups of customers during the last five

fiscal years:</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="99%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:99.96%;">

 <tr>

  <td width="21%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:21.14%;">

  <p align="center" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-align:center;text-indent:-10.0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>
