  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.4%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">101.7</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.32%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">1,224</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.92%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.4%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">175.3</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.32%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">1,435</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.42%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.92%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.4%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">192.2</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.42%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.32%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">1,518</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.3%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

</table>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>





<div style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">



<hr size="1" width="25%" noshade color="black" align="left">



</font></font></div>





<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><sup><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">1</font></font></sup><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In thousands of long tons (2,240

pounds).</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><sup><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">2</font></font></sup><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Consists of recycled metal that

is not processed by the Metals Recycling Business.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company sells

recycled metals to foreign and other domestic steel producers or their

representatives and to the Steel Manufacturing Business.&#160; The Company has developed long-standing

relationships with Asian and U.S. steel producers.&#160; The Company&#146;s Asian recycled metals customers are located

principally in China, Thailand, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan.&#160; To serve these customers more effectively,

the Company operates a wholly-owned subsidiary, SSI International Far East

Ltd., in Seoul, South Korea.&#160; Additionally,

the Company uses representatives in Tokyo, Japan to provide market data. &#160;The Company believes these representatives

not only enhance the Company's service to its Asian customers, but also provide

a valuable local presence and source of information in these markets.&#160; The Metals Recycling Business&#146; five largest

customers accounted for 45% of recycled metals sales to unaffiliated

customers.&#160; However, the Company's

recycled metals customers vary from year to year due to demand, relative

currency values and other factors.&#160; All

recycled metals sales are denominated in U.S. dollars and substantially all

significant recycled metals shipments to foreign customers are supported by

letters of credit.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Historically, ferrous

recycled metals prices have on average increased over the long term; such

prices, however, are subject to market cycles.&#160;

Prices for foreign recycled metals shipments are generally established

through a competitive bidding process.&#160;

The Company generally negotiates domestic prices based on export price

levels.&#160; Foreign recycled metals sales

contracts typically provide for shipment within 45 to 90 days after the price

is agreed to, which, in most cases, includes freight.&#160; Over the last two years there have been a number of attempts by

competitors and others to use e-commerce via the Internet for the sale of

recycled metals.&#160; To date none of these

efforts have had a meaningful impact on the business.&#160; The Company attempts to respond to changing export price levels

by adjusting its purchase prices at its metals recycling yards to maintain its

operating margin dollars per ton. &#160;However, the Company's ability to fully maintain its operating

margin per ton through periods of rapidly declining prices can be limited by

the impact of lower purchase prices on the volume of recycled metals flowing to

the Company from marginal unprocessed metal suppliers.&#160; Accordingly, the Company believes it

benefits from rising recycled metals prices, which provide the Company greater

flexibility to maintain or widen both margins and unprocessed metals flow into

its yards.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Sources of Unprocessed Metals.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;"> The most common forms of raw metals purchased by the Company are

wrecked automobiles, railroad cars, railroad tracks, machinery, home

appliances, and demolition metal from buildings and other obsolete

structures.&#160; The metals are acquired

from drive-in sellers at posted prices at the Company's twelve metals recycling

yards, from drop boxes at over 1,000 industrial sites and through negotiated

purchases from railroads and other large suppliers.&#160; The Company purchases unprocessed metals from a large number of

suppliers, including railroads, industrial manufacturers, automobile salvage

yards, metals dealers and individuals.&#160;

Metals recycling yards situated nearest to unprocessed metals sellers

and major transportation routes have a competitive advantage because of the

significance of freight charges relative to the value of metals.&#160; The Company's Portland yard benefits from

northwestern rail, highway and water transportation routes allowing it to

attract sellers from Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Utah, Nevada and

Northern California.&#160; The Eugene, Grants

Pass, White City and Bend yards are smaller facilities that serve as collection

points from central and southern Oregon.&#160;

These yards primarily use trucks and railroads to transport their

products.&#160; The Oakland yard gives the

Company sourcing capability in the San Francisco Bay area, one of the largest

metropolitan regions in the country. The Sacramento, Fresno, and Reno yards are

smaller facilities that serve as collection points for unprocessed metals from

the central valley of California and Western Nevada and are served by rail and

trucks.&#160; The Company's Tacoma yard,

along with its Anchorage, Alaska yard, collects unprocessed metals from Seattle

and the entire Puget Sound area as well as from throughout Washington, Montana,

Idaho, Alaska, and Western Canada.&#160;

Product is shipped and received via rail, truck and water (e.g. ship or

barge).&#160; No single supplier accounted

for more than 5% of the unprocessed metals purchased by the Company during the

last fiscal year.</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Metals Recycling.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Company processes raw metal

by cleaning, sorting, shearing and shredding it into metal pieces of a size,

density and purity required by customers for introduction into their melting

furnaces.&#160; Smaller, denser pieces of

recycled metals are more valuable because they melt more easily than larger

pieces and more completely fill a steel mill&#146;s furnace charge bucket.&#160; Over 80% of the ferrous metals collected by

the Company's metals recycling facilities requires processing before sale.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Seven of the Company's twelve wholly owned metals

recycling facilities operate large capacity guillotine-style shears for cutting

large pieces of ferrous metal into smaller, more saleable pieces.&#160; At eight of the facilities, the Company also

has large scissor shears mounted on cranes that move about the yards and cut

bulky pieces of metal into sizes that can be further processed by the

guillotine shears.&#160; These mobile shears

are capable of reducing a railroad boxcar to useable recycled metal in approximately

30 minutes.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The

Portland and Oakland facilities each operate a large auto shredder capable of

processing up to 1,500 tons of metal per day.&#160;

In fiscal 2000, the Tacoma facility completed the installation of a

state-of-the-art shredder capable of shredding over 2,000 tons per day.&#160; These shredders reduce automobile bodies and

other light gauge sheet metal into fist-size pieces of shredded recycled metal

in seconds.&#160; The shredded material is

then carried by conveyor under magnetized drums, which attract the ferrous

recycled metal and separate it from the nonferrous metals and other material

(fluff) found in the shredded material, resulting in a relatively pure and

clean shredded steel product.&#160; The

nonferrous metal and fluff then pass through a separator that removes the

fluff.&#160; In Oakland, the nonferrous

metals are further processed using a sink float method to separate aluminum

from other metals based on the differences in their specific gravities.&#160; The remaining nonferrous metals are either

hand sorted and graded before being sold or sold unsorted.&#160; During fiscal 2000, the Portland yard

installed a new indoor nonferrous sorting system, which allows for greater

recovery of high value nonferrous products.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The new shredder at the Tacoma facility has significantly

expanded the processing capacity at that site.&#160;

Additionally, this new shredder is designed to provide a denser product,

which can be more efficiently used by steel mills and to handle materials

which, in the past, could not have been shredded.&#160; During fiscal 2002, the Company will complete the upgrade of its

Tacoma nonferrous sorting capabilities to increase the capacity and improve the

nonferrous recovery from the automobile shredding process.&#160; In fiscal 2002, the addition of the Portland

de-watering process will also be completed, lowering the cost of auto shredder

residue disposal.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Deep Water Terminal Facilities.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Company delivers recycled

metals to foreign steel producers by ship.&#160;

The Company achieves cost efficiencies by operating deep water terminal

facilities at its Portland, Tacoma and Oakland facilities.&#160; As a result, the Company is generally not

subject to berthing delays often experienced by users of unaffiliated terminal

facilities. The Oakland dock also has a berth serviced by a bulk loading

conveyor for loading shredded metal as well as a concrete wharf with a 40-ton

container crane.&#160; The Tacoma marine

terminal is serviced by a 250-ton gantry crane and one 40-ton crane.&#160; A new dock and bulkhead were completed at

the Tacoma yard during fiscal 1999.&#160; The

Portland dock has three operating berths for ships and two tie-up berths, and

is equipped with three 60-ton cranes and one 30-ton crane for loading and

unloading heavy materials, and a bulk loading conveyor capable of loading up to

700 tons of shredded recycled metals per hour directly into a ship's hold.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Oakland and Tacoma terminals are used extensively for

loading metals shipments to the Company's foreign customers. The Portland

terminal primarily and, to a lesser extent, the Oakland and Tacoma terminals

also sell docking, loading and warehousing services to unrelated parties.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Competition.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Company competes for both the purchase

of unprocessed metals from suppliers and the sale of processed recycled metals

to finished steel producers.&#160;

Competition for unprocessed metals purchased in the Metals Recycling

Business&#146; markets comes primarily from larger, well financed competitors and

those who buy product on the behalf of mills.&#160;

Other competitors include smaller metals yards and dealers who buy

recycled metals directly.&#160; The Company

also competes with smaller, regional shredder operators and dealers who can

impact prices and volumes of certain commodities in smaller geographic areas.&#160; The predominant competitive factors impacting

the Company&#146;s recycled metals sales and its ability to obtain unprocessed

metals are price, including shipping costs, availability, reliability of

service and product quality.</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company competes with a number of U.S. and foreign

recycled metals processors for export sales.&#160;

Price, including shipping costs, and availability are the most important

competitive factors, but reliability and quality are also important.&#160; During the last two years, the Company has

experienced increasing competition from countries that were part of the former

Soviet Union.&#160; The quality of their

product is generally good and their pricing is generally aggressive, as they

tend to operate for the generation of cash flow versus focusing on traditional

income and return on investment theory.&#160;

However, these countries often lack the infrastructure needed to

guarantee time of delivery.&#160; The Company

believes that its size and locations allow it to compete effectively with other

U.S. and foreign metals recyclers.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Seasonality.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Company makes a number of large ferrous

metals shipments to foreign steel producers each year.&#160; The Company's control over the timing of

shipments is limited by customers' requirements, shipping schedules and other

factors.&#160; Variations in the number of

shipments from quarter to quarter result in fluctuations in quarterly revenues,

earnings, and inventory levels.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Backlog.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; On August 31, 2001, the Company's Metals

Recycling Business had a backlog of firm orders of $23.9 million, as compared

to $18.4 million on August 31, 2000.&#160;

All of the backlog on August 31, 2001 was related to export shipments.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="JointVentures"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Joint Ventures</font></font></u></b></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">The Company has invested in certain joint ventures

which process and sell </font>recycled metals </font><font style="letter-spacing:0pt;">to third parties and other joint ventures that supply </font>unprocessed

metals <font style="letter-spacing:0pt;">to the Company&#146;s operations and other

metals buyers.&#160; The Company&#146;s joint

ventures with Hugo Neu Corporation recognized revenues of $438.2 million in

fiscal 2001 and $437.7 million in fiscal 2000.&#160;

The Pick-N-Pull Auto Dismantling joint venture recognized revenues of

$37.8 million in fiscal 2001 and $34.9 million in fiscal 2000.&#160; Other joint ventures recognized revenues of

$25.3 million in fiscal 2001 and $29.6 million in fiscal 2000.</font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">I.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Joint Ventures in the Metals Recycling

Business</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The Company owns interests in five joint

ventures that are engaged in buying, processing, and selling primarily ferrous

metal.&#160; The Company is a 50% partner in

four of these joint ventures and is a 30% partner in another smaller joint

venture.&#160; These joint ventures process

and sell approximately 3 million long tons of ferrous <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals </font>per year.&#160; Through

these joint ventures, the Company participates in the management of 26 <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals </font>collection and processing

facilities, including export terminals in Los Angeles, California, Everett,

Massachusetts, Portland, Maine, Providence, Rhode Island and Jersey City, New

Jersey and 21 feeder yards.&#160; At the

feeder yards metal is collected, processed and then transported to one of the

joint venture&#146;s export terminals for subsequent sale or sold directly to

domestic purchasers.&#160; The Company also

owns a 50% interest in two smaller metals recycling joint ventures in the

Western United States.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Metals <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Processing&nbsp;</font>and

Supply.&#160; </font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">The joint

ventures predominantly produce shredded <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">recycled

metal </font>and other grades of ferrous <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">recycled

metal</font>, primarily heavy melting and premium grades.&#160; Like the Metals Recycling Business, the

joint ventures process <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals </font>by

shredding, sorting, baling, shearing or cutting the <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals </font>into pieces suitable for melting.&#160; Processed <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals

are</font> either inventoried for later shipment or shipped directly by rail,

truck, ship or barge to foreign or domestic steel mills.</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Deep Water Terminal Facilities.&#160; </font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">Through its joint ventures, the Company

participates in the management of export terminals in Los Angeles, California,

Everett, Massachusetts, Portland, Maine, Providence, Rhode Island and Jersey

City, New Jersey.&#160; The joint ventures

deliver by ship <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">recycled metals </font>to

steel producers throughout the world. As a result of owning or leasing these

facilities, the joint ventures are not subject to berthing delays often

experienced by users of unaffiliated terminal facilities.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">In fiscal 2001, the export

terminal in New Jersey began a dredging project on a private channel adjacent

to the terminal as well as a small portion of the Hudson River.&#160; The project is expected to provide the

Company's&#160; New Jersey joint venture with

numerous benefits that include increasing the depth of water in the private

channel, which will allow export ships to be loaded entirely alongside the

export yard.&#160; Currently, export ships

can only load a portion of their cargoes alongside the yard due to the

channel&#146;s depth and the balance of the cargo has to be loaded by shuttling

barges between the export yard and the ship anchored in the bay.&#160; The elimination of the shuttle system and

the related &#147;double handling&#148; is expected to significantly reduce loading costs

at this yard.&#160; It is anticipated that a

significant portion of the dredging costs will be financed by a tax exempt low

interest&#160; rate bond, requiring

interest-only payments for 35 years.&#160;

The bond is partially supported by local governmental agencies.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Competition.&#160; </font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">The

predominant competitive factors which impact the joint ventures&#146; ability to

obtain unprocessed metals as a raw material and recycled metals sales are

price, including shipping costs, availability, reliability of service and

product quality.&#160; See Competition in the

Metals Recycling Business section of this report.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">II.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Joint

Venture Suppliers of Metals</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company is a 50%

partner in a joint venture which operates seventeen self-service used auto

parts yards in central California and the Bay Area, two yards in Nevada, and

one yard each in Texas, Utah, Illinois, and Indiana.&#160; Customers purchase parts that they remove themselves from wrecked

automobiles purchased by the joint venture and displayed in its yards.&#160; The Company then has a right of first

refusal to purchase the picked over car bodies for shredding at the Oakland

metals recycling operation.&#160; During

fiscal 2001, the Company purchased substantially all the car bodies generated

in California by this joint venture.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></b></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is also a 50%

partner in two joint ventures operating out of Richmond, California which are

industrial plant demolition contractors.&#160;

These joint ventures dismantle industrial plants, perform environmental

remediation, resell any machinery or pieces of steel that are salvaged from the

plants in a usable form, and sell other recovered metals, primarily to the

Company.&#160; During fiscal 2001, the

Company purchased substantially all of the ferrous metals generated by these

joint venture.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company purchased 191,400 and 236,400 long tons of

ferrous metals from its joint ventures in fiscal 2001 and 2000,

respectively.&#160; Terms are negotiated at

arms-length between the Company and the other partners to the joint ventures.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="SteelManufacturingBusiness"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Steel

Manufacturing Business</font></font></u></b></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company's Steel Manufacturing Business is conducted

by its wholly owned subsidiary, Cascade Steel Rolling Mills, Inc., located in

McMinnville, Oregon (approximately 45 miles southwest of Portland).&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business' mini-mill

was established in 1968, acquired by the Company in 1984 and was significantly

renovated in the 1990&#146;s.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">Since

fiscal 1991, the Company has invested over $135 million to improve and

modernize the machinery and equipment at the Steel Manufacturing Business.&#160; During fiscal 1991, a new computerized,

higher capacity melt shop was completed and brought on line.&#160; The melt shop is more efficient and is

capable of processing 700,000 tons annually, compared with less than 400,000

tons for the previous melt shop.&#160; In

fiscal 1996, the Company finished the installation of a second rolling mill

(Rolling Mill #2).&#160; Rolling Mill #2 is

state-of-the-art and able to produce more finished goods with fewer

operators.&#160; In fiscal 1997, the Company

installed a rod block and finishing equipment at Rolling Mill #2 which allowed

the Steel Manufacturing Business to expand and enhance its product line.&#160; </font>In the summer of 2001, the Company

began the installation of a static var compensator which, when completed by the

end of calendar 2001, will provide a more uniform electric power supply for the

steel manufacturing process and decrease the amount of electricity used for each

ton produced. This enhancement is expected to increase efficiency and

production in the billet making process which will allow the Steel

Manufacturing Business to take advantage of the greater efficiencies gained at

Rolling Mill #2.</font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;">&nbsp;</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Products and Marketing.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Steel Manufacturing

Business produces rebar, merchant bar, wire rod, coiled rebar and specialty

products such as studded fence posts, grape stakes and special sections.&#160; Sales of these products during the last five

fiscal years were as follows:</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>
