  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.48%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">50</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.48%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">28.1</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.86%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">68</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.9%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

 <tr>

  <td width="19%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:19.52%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Total</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.92%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.56%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">159.4</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.48%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">546</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.92%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.56%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">192.4</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.48%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">666</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.92%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.56%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">172.7</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.48%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">571</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.92%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.56%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">187.4</font></font><sup><font face="Times"><font style="font-family:Times;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">2</font></font></sup></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.48%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">553</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.92%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="5%" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:5.56%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">182.4</font></font><sup><font face="Times"><font style="font-family:Times;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">2</font></font></sup></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.44%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.86%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">546</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:.9%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

</table>





<div style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:4.5pt 0in 2.7pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">



<hr size="1" width="25%" noshade color="black" align="left">



</font></font></div>





<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><sup><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">1</font></font></sup><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160; In thousands of short tons (2,000 pounds).</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><sup><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">2</font></font></sup><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160; Does not include billet sales of $4.0

million in 1998 and $1.3 million in 1997.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Rebar is steel rod used to increase the tensile strength

of poured concrete.&#160; Merchant bar

consists of round, flat, angle and square steel bars used by fabricators or

manufacturers to produce a wide variety of products, including gratings, steel floor

and roof joints, safety walkways, ornamental furniture, stair railings and farm

equipment. Wire rod is steel wire used by fabricators to produce a variety of

products such as chain link fencing, nails, wire and stucco netting. Coiled

rebar is rebar delivered on coils rather than in flat lengths, a method

preferred by some fabricators.&#160;

Specialty products include fence posts and other finished products.&#160; The Company's fence posts are designed to

support barbed wire and are sold primarily to the agricultural industry.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Steel Manufacturing

Business sells directly from its plant in McMinnville, Oregon and from its

distribution centers located in El Monte (Los Angeles area), Stockton and

Montebello, California.&#160; The

distribution centers facilitate sales by holding a ready inventory of products

close to major customers for just-in-time delivery.&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business communicates regularly with

major customers to determine their anticipated needs and plans its rolling mill

production schedule accordingly.&#160; The

Steel Manufacturing Business also produces and inventories a mix of products

forecasted to meet the needs of other customers.&#160; Shipments to customers are made by common carrier, either truck

or rail.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">During fiscal 2001, the Steel Manufacturing Business sold

its steel products to approximately 500 customers primarily located in the 10

western states.&#160; In that period,

approximately 45% of the Steel Manufacturing Business' sales were made to

customers in California.&#160; The Steel

Manufacturing Business' customers are principally steel service centers,

construction industry subcontractors, steel fabricators, and major farm and

wood product suppliers.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Steel Manufacturing Business' 10 largest customers

accounted for approximately 49% of its revenues during fiscal 2001.&#160; A single customer, Davis Wire Corp.,

accounted for 10% of the Company&#146;s consolidated revenues.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font></b>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Recycled Metals</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;"> <b><font style="font-weight:bold;">Supply.</font></b>&#160; The Company believes it operates the only

mini-mill in the United States, which has the ability to obtain its entire

recycled metals requirement from its own affiliated metals recycling

operations.&#160; The demand for steel

recycled metals has intensified with the increase in the number and capacity of

steel producers both in the U.S. and overseas.&#160;

There have at times been regional shortages of recycled metals with some

mills being forced to pay higher prices for recycled metals shipped from other

regions or to temporarily curtail operations.&#160;

The Company's Metals Recycling Business currently supplies the Steel Manufacturing

Business both with recycled metals that it has processed and with recycled

metals that it has purchased from third-party processors.&#160; See &quot;Metals Recycling Business&quot;.

The Metals Recycling Business is also able to deliver to the Steel Manufacturing

Business an optimal mix of recycled metal grades to achieve maximum efficiency

in its melting operations.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Energy Supply.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; Electricity and natural gas represented

approximately 7% and 4%, respectively, of the Steel Manufacturing Business'

cost of goods sold in the year ended August 31, 2001.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Steel Manufacturing Business purchases hydroelectric

power from McMinnville Water &amp; Light Company (McMinnville), a municipal

utility, and is McMinnville's largest customer. The Steel Manufacturing

Business signed a new five-year contract with McMinnville that expires

September 30, 2006.&#160; McMinnville obtains

power from the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) and then resells it to the

Steel Manufacturing Business at its cost plus a fixed charge per kilowatt hour

and a 3% city surcharge.&#160; In fiscal

2001, the Steel Manufacturing Business paid an average of $0.03 per kilowatt

hour used.&#160; The favored rate McMinnville

obtains from BPA is for firm power; therefore, the Steel Manufacturing Business

is not forced to sacrifice the reliability of its power supply for a lower

interruptible power rate as is the case with certain other mini-mills.&#160; On October 1, 2001, rates for certain

electricity-related services increased up to 46% due to increased demand on the

West Coast and lower supplies.&#160; However,

the Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; actual electricity charges did not increase

to this extent in October.&#160; Because of

the curtailment in operations discussed further below, the Steel Manufacturing

Business has been able to alter its production schedule to take advantage of

lower, off-peak rates.&#160; The BPA can

adjust rates every six months and McMinnville will change rates accordingly.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Steel Manufacturing Business purchases natural gas

for use in the reheat furnaces from IGI Resources of Boise, Idaho, pursuant to

a contract that obligates the business to purchase minimum amounts of gas at a

fixed rate or pay a demand charge.&#160; The

contract expires on October 31, 2003.&#160;

Rates for fiscal 2002 will decrease approximately 10% compared with

fiscal 2001.&#160; All natural gas used by

the Steel Manufacturing Business must be transmitted by a single pipeline owned

by Northwest Natural Gas Company (Northwest) that also serves local residential

customers of Northwest.&#160; To protect

against interruptions in gas supply, the Steel Manufacturing Business maintains

stand-by propane gas storage tanks, which have the capacity to hold enough gas

to operate one of the rolling mills for at least three days without refilling.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Manufacturing Operations and Equipment.</font></font></b>&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business' melt shop

includes a 100-ton capacity electric-arc furnace and a five-strand continuous

billet caster.&#160; The melt shop is highly

computerized and automated.&#160; The 100-ton

capacity of the furnace accommodates larger, less expensive grades of scrap,

resulting in recycled metals cost savings.&#160;

Energy savings result in part from efficiencies of the larger furnace,

but also as a result of post-combustion equipment added to the furnace in

1995.&#160; This technology injects oxygen

into the furnace during melting operations which creates energy by combusting

carbon monoxide.&#160; The melt shop also has

enhanced steel chemistry refining capabilities, permitting the mill to produce

higher margin products using special alloy quality grades of steel not

currently produced by other mills on the West Coast.&#160; In the summer of 2001, the Company began the installation of a

static var compensator which, when completed by the end of calendar 2001, will provide

a more uniform electric power supply for the steel manufacturing process and

decrease the amount of electricity used for each ton produced. This enhancement

is expected to increase efficiency and production in the billet making process

which will allow the Steel Manufacturing Business to take advantage of the

greater efficiencies gained at Rolling Mill #2.</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">During fiscal 2001, 2000, and 1999, the

melt shop produced 680,000, 631,000, and 628,000 tons of billets,

respectively.&#160; With the addition of the

previously mentioned static var compensator, the Company believes that the melt

shop can produce over 700,000 tons of billets per year when operating at

capacity.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Billets produced by the melt shop are

reheated in one of two natural gas-fueled reheating furnaces and then drawn

red-hot through one of two rolling mills.&#160;

Rolling Mill #1, a 17-stand mill, was completed in July 1986.&#160; The mill is computerized, allowing for

efficient synchronized operations of the rolls and related equipment.&#160; The computer controls facilitate the

reconfiguration of the rolls to produce different products, thus reducing

costly downtime.&#160; The computer controls

include a self-diagnostic system that detects and identifies electronic and

mechanical malfunctions in Rolling Mill #1.&#160;

In 1994, the <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Steel Manufacturing

Business</font> completed the installation of in-line straightening, stacking

and bundling equipment on the end of Rolling Mill #1.&#160; The addition of this equipment has permitted the <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Steel Manufacturing Business</font> to improve the

quality of its products and to produce its merchant bar products more

efficiently by automating the straightening and bundling function.&#160; It has also permitted the Steel

Manufacturing Business to expand its higher-margin merchant bar product line.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Rolling

Mill #2, a technologically advanced 18-stand mill, was completed in February

1996.&#160; The mill is computerized,

allowing for efficient synchronized operations of the rolls and related

equipment.&#160; The computer controls facilitate

the reconfiguration of the rolls to produce different products, thus reducing

costly downtime.&#160; The computer controls

include a self-diagnostic system that detects and identifies electronic and

mechanical malfunctions in the mill.&#160;

The <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Steel Manufacturing Business</font>

completed the installation of a rod block at Rolling Mill #2 in February

1997.&#160; The rod block allows the Steel

Manufacturing Business to enhance its product mix through the production of

coiled rebar and wire rod.&#160; In addition,

the ability of Rolling Mill #2 to produce the <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Steel

Manufacturing Business</font>&#146; existing cut-to-length rebar products permits it

to increase its production of higher-margin merchant bar products at Rolling

Mill #1 and also increases its flexibility to adjust its product mix among

rebar, merchant bar and wire rod products to respond to relative demand and

price conditions among other products.&#160;

The Company continues to expect that Rolling Mill #2 will expand the

Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; rolling capacity, based on anticipated product

mix, to about 700,000 tons annually.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Historically, the Steel Manufacturing Business' melt shop

and rolling mills are each shut down for one week twice each year for

comprehensive maintenance (in addition to normal weekly maintenance performed

throughout the year).&#160; During these

periods a significant amount of the equipment in the mills is dismantled,

inspected and overhauled.&#160; In January

2001, the Steel Manufacturing Business began to curtail production in the

rolling mills, and in August 2001 began curtailing production in the melt

shop.&#160; Declining markets, due to the

slowing US economy and competition from imports and a change in product mix led

to this decision.&#160; The Company wanted to

better match production with demand in order to manage inventory.&#160; The melt shop, which historically operated

24 hours per day, seven days per week, slowed to 24 hours per day, five days

per week in August 2001.&#160; The rolling

mills, which historically ran simultaneously, have operated individually since

January 2001.&#160; Rolling Mill #1 is

working one week per month, and Rolling Mill #2 is working the other three

weeks per month.&#160; Future plans are

uncertain and depend upon market demand, product pricing and other factors.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Transportation.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business makes

extensive use of rail transportation for shipment of its products to its

distribution center and customers in California and for the shipment of

recycled metals to the mill both from the Metals Recycling Business&#146; yards and

other metal recyclers in Southern Oregon and California.&#160; As a result, the Company believes it is one

of the largest customers of Union Pacific Corporation and the largest customer

for northbound freight. The Company believes this position enables the Company

to obtain favorable rates which permit the Steel Manufacturing Business to

compete with mills that are closer to California markets.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Competition.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business competes

predominantly with the following Western U.S. steel producers for sales of

rebar and merchant bar: Birmingham Steel Corporation in Seattle, Washington;

NUCOR Corporation in Plymouth, Utah; Tamco in Los Angeles, California; North

Star Steel Company in Kingman, Arizona; and Chaparral Steel Company in

Midlothian, Texas.&#160; The Steel

Manufacturing Business also competes for sales of wire rod with the

aforementioned North Star Steel Company mini-mill and an Oregon Steel Mills,

Inc. plant located in Pueblo, Colorado, along with other domestic and foreign

producers.&#160; Other domestic mills

generally do not compete in the Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; market area

because of transportation costs.&#160; The

principal competitive factors in the Steel Manufacturing Business' market are

price (including freight cost), availability, quality and service.&#160; Certain of the Steel Manufacturing Business'

competitors have substantially greater financial resources than the Steel

Manufacturing Business. U.S. steel manufacturers have historically faced

competition from foreign steel producers.&#160;

During fiscal 2001, the Steel Manufacturing Business continued to

experience significant competition from low-priced steel products imported by

these Asian companies, which was a direct result of the Asian financial

crisis.&#160; The competition from low-priced

steel products from Asian countries is anticipated to continue into fiscal

2002.&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business

also continues to experience limited competition from Mexican steel mills in

the Southern California market. </font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">On June 5, 2001, President Bush asked the

U.S. International Trade Commission to investigate the effects of steel imports

on the domestic steel industry under Section 201 of the 1974 Trade Act. The

Commission has determined that some steel imports are a threat to domestic

steel producers, and the President could impose safeguard restrictions on steel

imports to aid the steel industry.&#160; It

is expected the President will rule on the safeguard restrictions, if any, by

the end of 2001.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font></b>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Seasonality.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business' revenues

can fluctuate significantly between quarters due to factors such as the

seasonal slowdown in the construction industry, which occurs from the late fall

through early spring, and in other industries it serves.&#160; In the past, the Steel Manufacturing

Business has generally experienced its lowest sales during the second quarter

of the fiscal year.&#160; The Company expects

this pattern to continue in the future.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Backlog.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business generally

ships products within days after the receipt of purchase orders.&#160; Backlogs are seasonal and would be larger in

fiscal quarters three and four.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="EnvironmentalMatters"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Environmental

Matters</font></font></u></b></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Compliance with environmental laws and regulations is a

significant factor in the Company's business.&#160;

The Company is subject to local, state, federal, and supranational

environmental laws and regulations concerning, among other matters, solid waste

disposal, air emissions, waste water disposal, dredging, and employee

health.&#160; Environmental legislation and

regulations have changed rapidly in recent years and it is likely that the

Company will be subject to even more stringent environmental standards in the

future.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Federal and state

environmental regulatory agencies have been investigating potential

contamination to a 5.5 mile stretch of the Willamette River in Portland, Oregon

referred to as the Portland Harbor.&#160; In

December 2000, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) named the

Portland Harbor as a Superfund site. However, the precise nature and extent of

any clean-up of the site, the parties to be involved, and the process to be

followed for such a clean-up have not yet been determined.&#160; The Oregon Department of Environmental

Quality (DEQ) has requested operating history and other information from

numerous persons and entities which own or conduct operations on properties

adjacent to or upland from the Portland Harbor.&#160; The DEQ has contacted Schnitzer Investment Corp. (SIC), a related

party, from whom the Company leases its metals recycling and deep water

terminal facility in Portland, Oregon, and requested that SIC perform a

voluntary preliminary investigation of that property.&#160; SIC has agreed to perform an investigation of the property.&#160; The Company is obligated under its lease

with SIC to bear all the costs relating to the investigation and remediation of

the property.&#160; Also, Crawford Street

Corporation, a subsidiary of the Company, owns property adjacent to the

Portland Harbor and has been requested by DEQ to perform a voluntary

preliminary investigation of its property.&#160;

While the cost of the investigation of these properties is not expected to

be material, no estimate has been made as to the cost of remediation, if

any.&#160; Accordingly, no accrual for the

remediation had been established as of August 31, 2001.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h3 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;text-decoration:underline;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;text-decoration:none;">Manufacturing Management, Inc.</font></font></b></h3>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 1994, Manufacturing

Management, Inc. (MMI), recorded a reserve for the estimated cost to cure

certain environmental liabilities.&#160; This

reserve was carried over to the Company's financial statements and at August

31, 2001 aggregated $17.7 million.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">General Metals of Tacoma,

Inc. (GMT), MMI&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary, owns and operates a recycled metals

facility located on the Hylebos Waterway, a part of Commencement Bay, which is

the subject of an ongoing environmental investigation and remediation project

by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Comprehensive

Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA). GMT and well

over 60 other parties were named potentially responsible parties (PRP&#146;s) for

the investigation and cleanup of contaminated sediment along the Hylebos

Waterway. GMT and five other PRP&#146;s voluntarily entered into an Administrative

Order on Consent with the EPA to fund a pre-remedial study of sediment

contamination and remediation alternatives. The study is now complete and in

the final stages of EPA review.&#160; The

Company has paid for its share of the study.&#160;

However, there are a variety of uncertainties regarding the clean-up of

this site, which impact the Company&#146;s ability to estimate its future potential

liabilities.&#160; A final consent decree for

the Hylebos Waterway has not been issued.&#160;

Additionally, significant uncertainties exist regarding the Company&#146;s

share of the costs to remediate this site.&#160;

The environmental liabilities above include the Company&#146;s estimate of

its liabilities related to this site based on information currently

available.&#160; GMT may also be named in a

claim for potential natural resource damages in Commencement Bay currently

under assessment by certain government agencies and others acting as natural

resource trustees.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">MMI is also a named PRP at two third-party sites at which

it allegedly disposed of transformers.&#160;

At one site, MMI entered into a settlement under which it agreed to pay

$825,000 towards remediation of the site.&#160;

Remediation of the site has been completed and it is now subject to a

five year monitoring program.&#160; The other

site has not yet been subject to significant remedial investigation.&#160; MMI has been named as a PRP at several other

sites for which it has agreed to de minimis settlements.&#160; In addition to the matters discussed above,

the Company's environmental reserve includes amounts for potential future

cleanup of other sites at which MMI has conducted business or has allegedly

disposed of other materials.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font></b>



<h3 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;text-decoration:underline;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;text-decoration:none;">Proler</font></font></b></h3>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">In 1996, prior to the Company&#146;s

acquisition of Proler, Proler recorded a liability for the probable costs to

remediate its properties.&#160; The Company

carried over the aggregate reserve to its financial statements upon acquiring

Proler, and $5.2 million remained outstanding on August 31, 2001.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">Between 1982 and 1987, MRI Corporation (MRI), a

subsidiary of Proler, operated a tin can shredding and detinning facility in

Tampa, Florida.&#160; In 1989 and 1992, the

EPA conducted a preliminary site investigation of this property and, in

December 1996, added the site to the &#147;National Priorities List&#148;.&#160; MRI and Proler, along with several other

parties, have been named as PRPs for the site by the EPA.&#160; Additionally, Proler and/or a subsidiary

have been named or identified as PRPs at several other sites.&#160; The probable costs associated with these

sites is in the aforementioned reserve.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">As part of the Proler acquisition, the

Company became a fifty-percent owner of Hugo Neu-Proler Company (HNP). HNP has

agreed, as part of its 1996 lease renewal with the Port of Los Angeles, to

conduct a multi-year, phased remedial clean-up project involving certain

environmental conditions on its metals recycling facility at its Terminal

Island site in Los Angeles, California, to be completed by the year 2002.&#160; Remediation includes limited excavation and

treatment of contaminated soils, paving, installation of a stormwater

management system, construction of a noise barrier and perimeter wall around

the facility, and groundwater monitoring.&#160;

The remaining estimated costs to remediate this property are included in

HNP&#146;s financial statements.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Metals

Recycling LLC (Metals) is a scrap metals processing business with locations in

Rhode Island and Massachusetts.&#160; The

members of Metals are one of the Company&#146;s Proler joint ventures and Metals

Recycling, Inc.&#160; On June 9, 1999, the

Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management (DEM) issued a Notice of

Violation (NOV) against Metals, alleging Metals had violated federal and state

regulations relating to the storage, management, and transportation of

hazardous waste.&#160; DEM imposed an

administrative penalty of $718,000.&#160;

Metals has filed an answer to the NOV in which it denied the allegations

and requested an adjudicatory hearing.&#160;

In July 1999, the DEM issued a NOV to Rhode Island Resource Recovery

Corporation (RIRRC), which included a civil penalty of $308,000, relating to

the alleged disposal of hazardous waste by Metals at a landfill operated by

RIRRC.&#160; Metals and RIRRC have denied the

DEM's allegations.&#160; RIRRC has settled with

DEM and RIRRC and Metals are discussing a possible contribution by Metals to RIRRC

with respect to that settlement.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">In

late January of 1999, federal and state officials searched Metal's Johnston,

Rhode Island and Worcester, Massachusetts facilities.&#160; Metals has been advised that the search was part of a state

criminal investigation into possible violations of state and federal hazardous

waste programs and a Rhode Island statute that prohibits the disposal of

out-of-state solid waste at the landfill operated by RIRRC.&#160; A grand jury has been empanelled to consider

the allegations.&#160; No proceedings have

been commenced against Metals or its officers.&#160;

The Company believes Metals has substantial defenses to the alleged

violations.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Metals&#146; results of operations for the past few years have

included accruals for the probable costs to remediate or settle the above

mentioned environmental situations.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Additionally, other Proler joint venture sites with

potential environmental clean-up issues have been identified.&#160; The estimated potential clean-up costs

associated with these sites have also been included in the aforementioned

reserve.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h3 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;text-decoration:underline;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;text-decoration:none;">Metals Recycling Business</font></font></b></h3>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">After the shredding of automobile bodies

and the separation of ferrous and salable nonferrous metals, the remaining auto

shredder residue (&#147;fluff&#148;) must be managed.&#160;

State and federal standards prescribe fluff sampling protocols which

require representative samples of fluff to be analyzed to determine if they are

likely to leach heavy metals, PCBs or other hazardous substances in excess of

acceptable levels.&#160; Fluff from the

Company&#146;s <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">metals recycling </font>operations

in Oakland and Tacoma undergo an in-line chemical stabilization treatment prior

to its beneficial use as an alternative daily landfill cover.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font></b>



<h3 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;text-decoration:underline;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;text-decoration:none;">Steel Manufacturing Business</font></font></b></h3>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Cascade Steel Rolling Mills, Inc.&#146;s steel mini-mill generates

electric arc furnace (EAF) dust, which is classified as a hazardous waste by

the EPA because of its zinc and lead content.&#160;

Currently, a majority of the EAF dust is shipped to a firm in the United

States that applies a treatment which allows the EAF dust to be delisted as

hazardous so it can be disposed of as a non-hazardous, solid waste. The

remaining volume of the Company&#146;s EAF dust is exported, pursuant to an annually

renewable export license, to a secondary smelter in Mexico that recycles EAF

dust to produce commercial grade zinc and lead.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Steel

Manufacturing Business</font>&#146; mini-mill operating permit under Title V of the

Clean Air Act Amendment of 1990, which governs certain air quality standards,

was issued in 1998 and expires in April 2003. The mini-mill is currently

permitted to melt up to 900,000 tons of <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">recycled

metals </font>per year and produce finished steel products totaling 450,000

tons for Rolling Mill #1 and 525,000 tons for Rolling Mill #2.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">As the mini-mill&#146;s production grows beyond current

levels, </font>the Steel Manufacturing Business has </font><font style="letter-spacing:0pt;">anticipated that it would need to enhance its

existing facilities to properly control increased emissions in order to remain

in compliance with the operating permit. </font>&#160;In fiscal 2001, the Steel Manufacturing Business <font style="letter-spacing:0pt;">installed an additional baghouse that is expected to

control emissions.&#160; The installation was

completed at a cost of $0.6 million. In fiscal year 2002, the baghouse will be

expanded further at an estimated cost of $0.3 million.</font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">It is not possible to predict the total size of all

capital expenditures or the amount of any increases in operating costs or other

expenses that may be incurred by the Company or its subsidiaries to comply with

environmental requirements applicable to the Company, its subsidiaries and

their operations, or whether all such cost increases can be passed on to

customers through product price increases.&#160;

Moreover, environmental legislation has been enacted, and may in the

future be enacted, to create liability for past actions that were lawful at the

time taken but which have been found to affect the environment and to increase

public rights of action for environmental conditions and activities.&#160; As is the case with steel producers and

recycled metals processors in general, if damage to persons or the environment

has been caused, or is in the future caused, by the Company's hazardous

materials activities or by hazardous substances now or hereafter located at the

Company's facilities, the Company may be fined and/or held liable for such damage

and, in addition, may be required to remedy the condition.&#160; Thus, there can be no assurance that

potential liabilities, expenditures, fines and penalties associated with

environmental laws and regulations will not be imposed on the Company in the future

or that such liabilities, expenditures, fines or penalties will not have a

material adverse effect on the Company.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company has, in the past, been found not to be in

compliance with certain environmental laws and regulations and has incurred

liabilities, expenditures, fines and penalties associated with such

violations.&#160; The Company&#146;s objective is

to maintain compliance.&#160; Efforts are

ongoing to be responsive to environmental regulations.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company believes that it is in material compliance

with currently applicable environmental regulations as discussed above and,

except as discussed above, does not anticipate any substantial capital

expenditures for new environmental control facilities during fiscal 2002 or

2003.</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h3 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;text-decoration:underline;"><a name="Employees"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Employees</font></font></u></b></a></h3>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">As of August 31, 2001, the Company had 989 full-time

employees, consisting of 458 employees at the Company's </font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">Metals

Recycling Business<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">, 462 employees at the

Steel Manufacturing Business, and 69 corporate administrative employees.&#160; Of these employees, 608 are covered by collective

bargaining agreements with twelve unions.&#160;

The Steel Manufacturing Business' contract with the United Steelworkers

of America covers 348 of these employees and expires on April 1, 2005.&#160; The Company believes that its labor

relations generally are good.</font></font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="Item2_Properties"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">ITEM 2.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; PROPERTIES</font></font></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company's Portland </font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">metals

recycling facility<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">, Portland deep water

terminal facilities, and the related buildings and improvements are located on

an approximately 120-acre industrial site owned by Schnitzer Investment Corp.

(SIC), a related party, and leased to the Company under a long-term lease.&#160; See Part III, Item 13 &quot;Certain

Relationships and Related Transactions.&quot;&#160;

Approximately 17 acres are occupied by the deep water terminal

facilities, and the balance is used by the </font>Metals Recycling Business<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">.</font></font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Sacramento recycled metals operations are located on

a 7-acre site, most of which is leased from SIC under a long-term lease.&#160; See Part III, Item 13 &quot;Certain

Relationships and Related Transactions.&quot;&#160;

The Pasco, Anchorage and Reno operations are located on sites leased

from third parties.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The following metals recycling operations are all located

on sites owned by the Company or subsidiaries:</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

 <tr>

  <td width="40%" valign="top" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:40.6%;">

</table>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Steel Manufacturing Business' steel mill and

administrative offices are located on an 83-acre site owned by the Steel

Manufacturing Business in McMinnville, Oregon.&#160;

The Steel Manufacturing Business also owns its 87,000 sq. ft.

distribution center in El Monte, California.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The equipment and facilities on each of the foregoing

sites are described in more detail in the descriptions of each of the Company's

businesses.&#160; The Company believes its

present facilities are adequate for operating needs for the foreseeable future.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company's principal executive offices are located at

3200 NW Yeon Avenue in Portland, Oregon in 20,000 sq. ft. of space leased from

SIC under long-term leases.&#160; See Part

III, Item 13 &quot;Certain Relationships and Related Transactions.&quot;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="Item3_LegalProceedings"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">ITEM 3.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; LEGAL

PROCEEDINGS</font></font></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Except as described above

under Part I, Item 1 &quot;Business -- Environmental Matters&quot;, the Company

is not a party to any material pending legal proceedings.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="Item4_SubmissionOfMattersToAVote"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">ITEM 4.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; SUBMISSION

OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS</font></font></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">No matters were submitted

to a vote of security holders during the fourth quarter of the fiscal year

ended August 31, 2001.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  <td width="59%" valign="top" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:59.6%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Vice President - Finance and Treasurer</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Kelly E. Lang</font></font></p>
