  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.1%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="15%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:15.34%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">4,507</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:2.48%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.1%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="15%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:15.34%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">3,450</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:2.4%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

 </tr>

</table>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The Joint Ventures in the Metals

Recycling Business predominantly sell recycled ferrous metal.&#160; The increase in revenues recognized by these

joint ventures is attributable to higher ferrous selling prices and an increase

in tonnage shipped.&#160; Also, fiscal 2000

revenues include a full year&#146;s results of a joint venture organized in the third

quarter of fiscal 1999.&#160; Shipments of

ferrous metal processed by the joint ventures increased to 2.8 million tons for

the year ended August 31, 2000 from 2.5 million tons in the prior year.&#160; The average selling price of ferrous

recycled metal increased during that period to $108 per ton from $87 per ton,

predominantly due to strengthening Asian and other foreign economies.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">In fiscal 2000, the Company&#146;s equity in

income from Joint Ventures in the Metals Recycling Business was adversely

affected by $1.1 million to reflect the Company&#146;s share of LIFO inventory

adjustments. In comparison, the results for fiscal 1999 benefited from $3.3

million of LIFO and other inventory adjustments.&#160; The Company&#146;s equity in income from the Joint Ventures in the

Metals Recycling Business for fiscal 1999 included the Company&#146;s $1.4 million

share of a gain recognized by one of the joint ventures from the sale of

property.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">Both revenues and income from the Joint Venture

Suppliers of Metal increased from fiscal 1999 to fiscal 2000 primarily due to

higher ferrous selling prices.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Interest Expense.&#160; </font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">Interest

expense increased $0.4 million due to increased average borrowings and higher

average interest rates.&#160; Average

borrowings of $107.4 million in fiscal 2000 exceeded average borrowings in

fiscal 1999 of $104.3 million.&#160; The

average interest rate for fiscal 2000 was 6.3% compared with 5.4% for fiscal

1999.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Gain (Loss) on Sale of Assets.&#160; </font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">In fiscal 2000, the Company and its

outside board members approved the sale of a ship leased by the Company from a

related party to export recycled metal.&#160;

The sale resulted in a $1.0 million loss. Fiscal 1999 results included

the Steel Manufacturing Business&#146; sale of its Union City, California mill depot,

resulting in a gain of $1.2 million.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Other Income.&#160; </font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">Other income

increased $1.3 million.&#160; During fiscal

2000, the Company received a $0.7 million settlement as a result of antitrust

litigation related to graphite electrodes pricing.&#160; In fiscal 1999, the Company received $1.0 million related to the

same antitrust settlement.&#160; Also, the

Company recognized additional interest income during fiscal 2000 of $1.9

million, related to advances to joint ventures, and $0.9 million of investment

income on assets related to the supplemental executive retirement plan due to

strong domestic financial markets. See Note 8.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Income Tax Provision.&#160;

</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">The Company&#146;s effective income tax rate decreased to 6% in

fiscal 2000 from 55% in fiscal 1999.&#160;

The decrease was primarily due to lower taxable income caused by utilization

of $8.6 million of net operating loss carryforwards (NOLs) that were acquired

as part of the 1996 acquisition of Proler.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">By acquiring Proler in 1996, the Company

succeeded to $31.4 million of NOLs incurred in Proler&#146;s pre- acquisition

years.&#160; Federal income tax law limits

the amount of Proler pre-acquisition NOLs that can be used by the Company to

$2.4 million per year.&#160; However, to the

extent the respective annual limit exceeds taxable income for a taxable year,

the unused excess may be carried over and used in subsequent taxable

years.&#160; Previous federal tax rules

limited the use of the Proler NOLs to offset taxable income only from the

acquired Proler entities.&#160; The new rules

now allow the Company to use the Proler NOLs to offset taxable income from all

sources.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">During fiscal 2000, federal income tax law changes were enacted that allow

the Company somewhat greater flexibility in utilizing the Proler NOLs.&#160; These changes allowed the Company to utilize

the annual limit of $2.4 million for fiscal 2000 as well as an additional $6.2

million of excess limit amounts from prior years.&#160; Subject to these annual utilization limits, the remaining $22.4

million of Proler NOLs may be used in future years until they expire at various

amounts in fiscal 2007 through 2012.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Liquidity

and Capital Resources.</font></font></u></b><u><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160; </font></font></u></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">For fiscal 2001, cash generated by operations was $8.6

million, compared to $35.4 million last year.&#160;

The decrease in cashflow provided by operations was primarily the result

of higher year-end inventories.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Capital expenditures totaled $9.3 million, $10.7 million,

and $12.0 million, for fiscal years 2001, 2000, and 1999, respectively. Because

of generally poor market conditions, coupled with larger capital investments in

the mid to late 1990&#146;s, the Company has focused its capital investment on

non-discretionary capital and investments with shorter paybacks.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">As part of its

acquisitions of Proler and MMI, the Company assumed environmental liabilities

aggregating $22.9 million as of August 31, 2001.&#160; The Company expects significant future cash outlays as it incurs

the actual costs relating to the remediation of such environmental liabilities.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The

Company has an unsecured revolving credit agreement of $200 million which

expires in June 2003.&#160; As of August 31,

2001, the Company had additional lines of credit available of $40<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font>million, which were uncommitted.&#160; In the aggregate, the Company had borrowings

outstanding under these lines of $83.9million

as of August 31, 2001.&#160; The Company&#146;s

debt agreements have certain restrictive covenants.&#160; As of August 31, 2001, the Company was in compliance with such

covenants.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant to a

stock repurchase program, the Company is authorized to repurchase up to 3

million shares of its stock when the market price of the Company&#146;s stock is not

reflective of management&#146;s opinion of an appropriate valuation of the

stock.&#160; Management believes that

repurchasing shares under these conditions enhances shareholder value and helps

the Company manage its targeted capital structure.&#160; As of August 31, 2001, a total of 1.24 million shares had been

purchased under this program.&#160; During

fiscal 2001, the Company repurchased 505,800 shares of its stock for a total of

$6.7 million.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company

believes that the current cash balance, internally generated funds and existing

credit facilities will provide adequate financing for capital expenditures,

working capital, joint ventures, stock repurchases, debt service requirements,

and future environmental obligations for the next year.&#160; In the longer term, the Company may seek to

finance business expansion with additional borrowing arrangements or additional

equity financing.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Factors That Could Affect Future Results.</font></font></b><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">&#160; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of

Financial Condition and Results of Operations contains forward-looking

statements, within the meaning of Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and

Section 21E of the Securities Act of 1934, and are made pursuant to the safe

harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.&#160; One can generally identify these

forward-looking statements because they contain &#147;expect&#148;, &#147;believe&#148;, and other

words which convey a similar meaning. One can also identify these statements as

they do not relate strictly to historical or current facts.&#160; Examples of factors affecting Schnitzer

Steel Industries, Inc.&#146;s wholly-owned operations and its joint ventures (the

Company) that could cause actual results to differ materially are the

following:</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">Cyclicality and General

Market Considerations</font></font></u><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">:&#160;

Selling prices for recycled metals are highly cyclical in nature and

subject to worldwide economic conditions.&#160;

In addition, the cost and availability of recycled metals are subject to

volatile supply and demand conditions beyond the Company&#146;s control, resulting

in periodic fluctuations in recycled metals prices.&#160; While the Company attempts to maintain margins by responding to

changing recycled metals selling prices through adjustments to its metals

purchase prices, the Company&#146;s ability to do so is limited by competitive factors

as well as the impact of lower prices on the volume of scrap available to the

Company.&#160; Moreover, increases in

recycled metals prices can adversely affect the operating results of the

Company&#146;s Steel Manufacturing Business because increases in steel prices

generally lag increases in ferrous recycled metals prices.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">The

steel industry is also highly cyclical in nature and sensitive to general

economic conditions.&#160; Future economic

downturns or a stagnant economy may adversely affect the performance of the

Company.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company expects to

continue to experience seasonal fluctuations in its revenues and net income.

Revenues can fluctuate significantly quarter to quarter due to factors such as

the seasonal slowdown in the construction industry, which is an important buyer

of the Company&#146;s finished steel products.&#160;

The timing and extent of the slowdown is also dependent on the weather.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company makes a

number of large ferrous recycled metals shipments to foreign steel producers

each year.&#160; Customer requirements,

shipping schedules and other factors limit the Company&#146;s control over the

timing of these shipments.&#160; Variations

in the number of foreign shipments from quarter to quarter will result in

fluctuations in quarterly revenues and earnings.&#160; The Company&#146;s expectations regarding ferrous metal sales prices

and volumes, as well as earnings, are based in part on the assumption that

orders from customers for larger shipments are not cancelled or delayed.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competition</font></font></u>:&#160; The recycled metals industry is highly competitive,

with the volume of purchases and sales subject to a number of competitive

factors, principally price.&#160; The Company

has competition from both large and numerous smaller companies in its markets

for the purchase of recyclable metals.&#160;

The Company competes with a number of U.S. and foreign recycled metals

processors for sales to foreign customers.</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The domestic steel

industry also is highly competitive.&#160;

Steel prices can be highly volatile and price is a significant

competitive factor.&#160; The Company competes

with several steel producers in the western U.S. for sales of its products. In

addition,&#160; in recent years, the Company

has experienced significant foreign competition, which is often subsidized by

large government agencies.&#160; There can be

no assurance that such competition will not increase in the future. On June 5,

2001, President Bush asked the U.S. International Trade Commission to

investigate the effects of steel imports on the domestic steel industry under

Section 201 of the 1974 Trade Act.&#160; On

October 22, 2001, the Commission reached affirmative determination that 12 of

the 33 product categories investigated were threatened by steel imports.&#160; Included in the 12 threatened product

categories were rebar and merchant bar, two of the Steel Manufacturing

Business&#146; larger volume, higher margin products.&#160; The President could impose safeguard restrictions on steel

imports to aid the steel industry.&#160; The

Commission will submit its findings and recommendations to the President in

December 2001.&#160; The Company cannot,

however, predict the recommendations or their impact on prices and operating

results.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Joint Ventures</font></font></u>:&#160; The Company has significant investments in

joint venture companies.&#160; The Company

does not manage the day-to-day activities of these businesses.&#160; As a result, it does not have the same

ability to control the operations and related financial results as it does with

its wholly owned businesses. These businesses are, however, impacted by many of

the same risk factors mentioned above. Therefore, it is difficult to predict

the financial results of these businesses.</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Energy Supply</font></font></u>:&#160; The Company and its joint ventures utilize

various energy sources to operate their facilities. In particular, electricity

and natural gas currently represent approximately 10% of the cost of steel

manufactured for the Company's Steel Manufacturing Business.&#160; The Steel Manufacturing Business purchases

hydroelectric power under long-term contracts from government sources which

rely on the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA).&#160; Historically, these contracts have had favorable prices and are

long-term in nature.&#160; The Company

recently signed a new five-year contract that expires in Septemer 2006.&#160; The BPA increased rates 46% as of October 1,

2001.&#160; Rates will be adjusted by the BPA

every six months from then forward.&#160; It

is not possible to predict future rate changes.</p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Steel Manufacturing

Business also has long-term contracts for natural gas.&#160; In October 2000, the Company entered into a

new contract, which is set to expire on October 31, 2002.&#160; The latest contract negotiations resulted in

rates that were 30% higher then the previous agreement.&#160; As this contract comes to an end, the

Company will attempt to negotiate a new long-term contract; however, it is not

possible to predict the terms of the contract.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The inability of the

Company to negotiate favorable terms of electricity, natural gas and other

energy sources could adversely affect the performance of the Company.</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">One should understand

that it is not possible to predict or identify all factors that could cause

actual results to differ from the Company&#146;s forward-looking statements.&#160; Consequently, the reader should not consider

any such list to be a complete statement of all potential risks or

uncertainties.&#160; Further, the Company

does not assume any obligation to update any forward-looking statement.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h5 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><a name="Item7a_QuantitativeAndQualitative"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 7(a).&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; QUANTITATIVE

AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK</font></font></a></h5>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The

Company has entered into certain market-risk sensitive financial instruments,

principally long-term debt. Sensitivity analysis was used to determine the

potential impact that market risk exposure may have on the fair values of the

company&#146;s financial instruments.&#160; The

Company has assessed the potential risk of loss in fair value from hypothetical

changes in interest rates by determining the effect on the present value of the

future cash flows related to those market sensitive instruments of such

changes.&#160; The discount rates used for

such present value computations were selected based on market interest rates in

effect at August 31, 2001, plus or minus 10 percent.&#160; A 10 percent change in interest rates, with all other variables

held constant, would result in an immaterial effect on consolidated earnings or

cash flows.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">This

discussion of market risks necessarily makes forward-looking statements.&#160; There can be no assurance that actual

changes in market conditions and rates and fair values will not differ

materially from those used in the sensitivity and fair value calculations

discussed.&#160; Factors which may cause

actual results to differ materially include, but are not limited to: greater

than 10 percent changes in interest rates or changes in income or cash flows

requiring significant changes in debt instruments or cash flows associated with

them.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">At

August 31, 2001, the Company held no derivatives.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><a name="Item8_FinancialStatementsAndSupplem"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 8.&#160; FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA</font></font></a></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in .25in .0001pt 13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in .25in .0001pt 13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">

 <tr>

  <td width="6%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:6.16%;">

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">

<p align="center" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;">&nbsp;</p>



<p align="center" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">REPORT

OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';letter-spacing:-.1pt;">To the Board of Directors and Shareholders of</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Schnitzer Steel Industries, Inc.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated balance

sheets and the related consolidated statements of operations, of shareholders&#146;

equity and of cash flows present fairly, in all material respects, the

financial position of Schnitzer Steel Industries, Inc. and its subsidiaries at

August 31, 2001 and 2000, and the results of their operations and their cash

flows for each of the three years in the period ended August 31, 2001, in

conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States

of America.&#160; These financial statements

are the responsibility of the Company's management; our responsibility is to

express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.&#160; We conducted our audits of these statements

in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States

of America, which require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain

reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of

material misstatement.&#160; An audit

includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures

in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and

significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial

statement presentation.&#160; We believe that

our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Portland, Oregon</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">September 28, 2001</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;">&nbsp;</p>



<p align="center" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">SCHNITZER

STEEL INDUSTRIES, INC.</font></font></p>

  </td>

<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="center" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 40.5pt .0001pt .25in;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The accompanying notes are an integral part of this

statement</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;"></font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Note 1 - Nature of Business and Summary of Significant

Accounting Policies:</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Nature of Business</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Schnitzer Steel

Industries, Inc. (the Company) operates a metal processing and recycling

business and, through its Cascade Steel Rolling Mills, Inc. subsidiary, a

mini-mill steel manufacturing business.&#160;

The Company&#146;s wholly owned recycling facilities are located in Alaska,

Washington, Oregon, California and Nevada.&#160;

</font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';">Additionally, through joint ventures, the Company

participates in the management of additional metals processing and recycling

businesses in Arizona, California, Connecticut, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana,

Maine, Massachusetts, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode

Island, Texas and Utah.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Principles of Consolidation</font></font></i></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The consolidated

financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned

subsidiaries.&#160; The Company, through subsidiaries,

holds a 50% interest in ten joint ventures and a 30% interest in one, which are

accounted for using the equity method. All intercompany transactions and

balances have been eliminated.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Inventories</font></font></i></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Inventories are

stated at the lower of cost or market.&#160;

Cost is determined using FIFO (first-in, first-out) and average cost

methods.&#160; See Note 2.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Property, Plant and Equipment</font></font></i></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost.&#160; Major renewals and improvements are

capitalized.&#160; Substantially all expenditures

for maintenance and repairs are charged to operations as incurred.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Depreciation is determined principally using the

straight-line method over estimated useful lives of approximately 20 to 40

years for buildings and approximately 3 to 10 years for equipment.&#160; Leasehold improvements are amortized over

the estimated useful lives of the property or the remaining lease term,

whichever is less.&#160; When assets are

retired or sold, the related cost and accumulated depreciation are removed from

the accounts and resulting gains or losses are included in other income.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h4 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long-lived

Assets</font></font></i></h4>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company evaluates the

recoverability of its long-lived assets, which include property, plant and

equipment, identifiable intangible assets and goodwill, periodically in accordance

with the provisions of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 121

(SFAS 121).&#160; The Company assesses its

long-lived assets for impairment at the lowest level for which there are

identifiable cash flows whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate

that the carrying amount may not be recoverable.&#160; Factors the Company considers important which could trigger an

impairment review include, but are not limited to, significant underperformance

relative to historical or projected future operating results, significant

changes in the manner in which an asset is utilized and substantial negative

industry or economic trends.&#160;&#160;&#160; If it is

determined that an impairment loss has occurred, the loss would be recognized

during the period incurred.&#160;&#160; The impairment

would be measured based on a projected discounted cash flow method using a

discount rate commensurate with the risk inherent in the Company&#146;s current

business model.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">On October 3, 2001, the FASB issued Statement of

Financial Accounting Standards No. 144, &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or

Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148; (SFAS 144).&#160;

SFAS 144 superceded SFAS 121.&#160;

SFAS 144 applies to all long-lived assets (including discontinued

operations) and consequently amends Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 30

&#147;Reporting Results of Operations &#150; Reporting the Effects of Disposal of a

Segment of a Business.&#160; SFAS 144

develops one accounting model for long-lived assets that are to be disposed of

by sale.&#160; SFAS 144 requires that

long-lived assets that are to be disposed of by sale be measured at the lower

of book value or fair value less cost to sell.&#160;

Additionally, SFAS 144 expands the scope of discontinued operations to

include all components of an entity with operations that (1) can be

distinguished from the rest of the entity and (2) will be eliminated from the

ongoing operations of the entity in a disposal transaction.&#160; SFAS 144 is effective for the Company for

all financial statements issued beginning September 1, 2002.&#160; The Company believes adoption of this

standard will not have a material effect on its financial statements.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font></i>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Goodwill</font></font></i></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Goodwill is being

amortized on the straight-line basis over 40 years.&#160; At August 31, 2001 and 2000, accumulated amortization aggregated

$8.7 million and $7.4 million, respectively.&#160;

Goodwill is periodically reviewed by the Company for impairments where

the fair value may be less than the carrying value.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">In July 2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued

Statements of Financial Accounting Standards Nos. 141 and 142 (SFAS 141 and

SFAS 142), &#147;Business Combinations&#148; and &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible

Assets.&#148;&#160; SFAS 141 replaces APB 16 and

eliminates pooling-of-interests accounting prospectively.&#160; It also provides guidance on purchase

accounting related to the recognition of intangible assets and accounting for

negative goodwill.&#160; SFAS 142 changes the

accounting for goodwilll from an amortization method to an impairment only

approach.&#160; Under SFAS 142, goodwill will

be tested annually and whenever events or circumstances occur indicating that

goodwill might be impaired.&#160; SFAS 141

and 142 are effective for all business combinations completed after June 30,

2001.&#160; Upon adoption of SFAS 142,

amortization of goodwill recorded for business combinations consummated prior

to July 1, 2001 will cease, and intangible assets acquired prior to July 1,

2001 that do not meet criteria for recognition under SFAS 141 will be

reclassified to goodwill.&#160; Companies are

required to adopt SFAS 142 for fiscal years beginning after December 15,

2001.&#160; The Company will adopt SFAS 142

on September 1, 2002, the beginning of fiscal 2003.&#160; In connection with the adoption of SFAS 142, the Company will be

required to perform a transitional goodwill impairment assessment.&#160; The Company has not yet determined the

impact these standards will have on its results of operations and financial

position.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Common Stock</font></font></i></p>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Each share of

Class A common stock is entitled to one vote and each share of Class B common

stock is entitled to ten votes.&#160;

Additionally, Class B common stock may be converted to one share of

Class A common stock.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h4 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Earnings

Per Share</font></font></i></h4>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Basic EPS is

computed based upon the weighted average number of common shares outstanding

during the period.&#160; Diluted EPS reflects

the potential dilution that would occur if securities or other contracts to

issue common stock were exercised or converted into common stock.&#160; The following represents a reconciliation

from basic EPS to diluted EPS (in thousands, except per share amounts):</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<div align="center">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">19</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.9%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="19%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:19.1%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:1.84%;">

<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Options with an exercise price greater than the average

market price were not included in the computation of diluted earnings per

share.&#160; These options totaled 1,021,000

in 2001 and</font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';"> <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">491,000 in 2000.</font></font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h4 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Interest

and Income Taxes Paid</font></font></i></h4>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Company paid $5.1</font></font><font face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';"> <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">million, $6.8 million, and $7.0 million in

interest during fiscal years 2001, 2000, and 1999, respectively.&#160; During fiscal 1999, the Company received net

income tax refunds of $6.2 million, and in fiscal years 2001 and 2000, the

Company paid $1.4 million,</font> and <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">$0.4

million respectively, in income taxes.</font></font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Fair Value of Financial Instruments</font></font></i></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Cash, receivables and current liabilities in the

consolidated financial statements are considered to reflect the fair value

because of the short-term maturity of these instruments.&#160; The fair value of long-term debt is deemed

to be the same as that reflected in the consolidated financial statements given

the variable interest rates on the significant credit facilities.&#160; There are no quoted prices for the Company&#146;s

investments in joint ventures accounted for on the equity method.&#160; A reasonable estimate of fair value could

not be made without incurring excessive costs.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Use of Estimates in Financial Statement Preparation</font></font></i></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The preparation of financial statements in accordance

with generally accepted accounting principles requires the Company to make

estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts and disclosures in

the financial statements.&#160; Actual

results could differ from those estimates.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Revenue Recognition</font></font></i></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">The Company recognizes revenue when it

has a contract or purchase order from a customer with a fixed price, the title

and risk of loss transfer to the buyer and collectibility is reasonability

assured.&#160; Title for both recycled metals

and finished steel products transfers upon shipment.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">In December 1999,

the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) issued Staff Accounting Bulletin

No. 101 (SAB 101), &#147;Revenue Recognition in Financial Statements&#148;, as amended by

SAB 101A and SAB 101B, which was required to be adopted by the Company by the

fourth quarter of the year ended August 31, 2001.&#160; SAB 101 codifies the SEC&#146;s views regarding the recognition of

revenues.&#160; The Company adopted SAB 101,

effective September 1, 2001; however, the impact on the Company&#146;s consolidated

financial position and consolidated results of operations was immaterial.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h4 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Environmental

Costs</font></font></i></h4>



<p align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The estimated future

costs for known environmental remediation requirements are accrued on an undiscounted

basis when it is probable that the Company has incurred a liability and the

related costs can be reasonably estimated.&#160;

When only a range of amounts is established, and no amount within the

range is better than another, the minimum amount of the range is recorded.&#160; Recoveries of environmental remediation

costs from other parties are recorded as assets when collection is probable.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<h4 align="left" style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing:-.1pt;line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">New

Accounting Pronouncement</font></font></i></h4>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">In July 2001, the FASB issued Statement of Financial

Accounting Standards No. 143 (SFAS 143), &#147;Accounting for Asset Retirement

Obligations&#148;.&#160; SFAS 143 requires

entities to record the fair value of a liability for an asset retirement

obligation in the period in which it is incurred.&#160; When the liability is initially recorded, the entity is required

to capitalize the cost by increasing the carrying amount of the related

long-lived asset.&#160; Over time, the

liability is accreted to its present value each period, and the capitalized

cost is depreciated over the useful life of the related asset.&#160; SFAS 143 is effective for fiscal years

beginning after June 15, 2002 and will be adopted by the Company effective

September 1, 2002.&#160; The Company has not

yet determined the impact this standard will have on its results of operations

and financial position.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font></b>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Note 2 - Inventories:</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Inventories consist of the following (in thousands):</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="15%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:15.2%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">13,194</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:3.24%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:3.2%;">

  <p align="right" style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">76,338</font></font></p>

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>

</table>



</div>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The production and accounting process utilized by the

Company to record recycled metals inventory quantities relies on significant

estimates, which can be affected by weight imprecisions, moisture and other

factors.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">In the first quarter of fiscal 2000, the Company changed

its method of accounting for recycled metals inventories from Last-In,

First-Out (LIFO) to First-In, First-Out (FIFO).&#160; Given the volatility of both prices and quantities, management

believes that accounting for inventories using the FIFO method better matches

revenues and expenses, and therefore is preferable.&#160; In addition, the method is consistent with its other inventory

pools.&#160; In accordance with Accounting

Principles Board No. 20, &#147;Accounting Changes,&#148; upon adoption, the Company

retroactively restated prior periods by applying the FIFO method of accounting

in prior periods.&#160; The effect of the

accounting change on net income as previously reported is as follows (in

thousands, except per share amounts):</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<div align="center">

  <td width="7%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt .7pt .7pt;width:7.38%;">

  <p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

  </td>

  </td>

 </tr>

</div>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">See discussion of additional leases with

related parties in Note 7.</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Note 4 - Long-Term Debt:</font></font></b></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Long-term debt consists of the following (in thousands):</font></font></p>

<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">At

August 31, 2001, the Company had a $200 million unsecured revolving credit

facility with its banks.&#160; Individual

advances outstanding under the line bear interest at floating rates.&#160; As of August 31, 2001, such rates averaged

3.89%.&#160; Interest is payable upon

maturity of each advance under the line.&#160;

The facility matures in June 2003, at which time all principal amounts

outstanding are due.&#160; <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">In addition to the above facility, the Company has

additional unsecured lines of credit totaling $40 million, all of which is

uncommitted.&#160; The committed bank credit

facilities and other borrowings contain financial covenants, including

covenants related to net worth, interest coverage and leverage.&#160; The Company was in compliance with these

covenants at August 31, 2001.</font></font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>



<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1 -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

</font></font>

years and thereafter are as follows (in thousands):</font></font></p>



<p style="font-family:'Courier New';font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&nbsp;</font></font></p>
